correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

Frederick C. Mosher
HAMILTON — Frederick C. Mosher, 81, of 9 Eaton Street, died Satur
day, July 4, 1992, at his home.
He was bom on May 28, 1911, in Lebanon, the son of Lewis and Pearl
Colvin Mosher.
He was a graduate of Hamilton High School and attended Colgate Uni
versity. ^
On July 3,193/ in Hamilton, Mr. Mosher married Alice Harrison. She
died in 1971. ^
During World War 11 Mr. Mosher worked as a civilian construction con
tractor, building soldier's housing in Alaska.
Mr. Mosher was also one of the contractors involved in the construction
of the present Oneida High School.
He had an avid interest in antiques and at one time was an active dealer
in the state.
Mr. Mosher was a life long resident of the Hamilton-Earlville area.
Surviving are one son, Barry Mosher, of Wilmington, Dela.; one sister,
Mrs. E. Jeril (Alta) Benedict of Hamilton; two grandchildren; one great
grandchild and several nieces and nephews. (See Death Notice.)
Mosher
■ tei
Funeral services for Frederick C.,
Mosher, will be Tuesday, July 7, at'
2 p.m. from the Paul Funeral Home^
3592 South St., Madison, with the'
Rev. David Hess, pastor of the First
Baptist Church, Hamilton, officiat-'
ing. Interment will be in Edgewood,
Memorial Park, Glen Mills, Pat"
There will be no calling hours. Con
tributions may be made in the_
memory of Mr. Mosher to the Amer-_;
ican Heart Association.
Frederick C. Mosher
HAMILTON — Frederick C.
Mosher, 81, of 9 Eaton St., died
Saturday at his home.
He was born in Lebanon and
was a life resident of the Hamil-
ton-Earlville area.
Surviving are a son, Barry of
Wilmington, Del.; a sister, Alta
Benedict of Hamilton; two grand
children; one great-grandchild;
and several nieces and nephews.
Services will be 2 p.m. Tuesday
at the Paul Funeral Home, 3592
South St., Madison. Burial will be
in Glen Mills, Pa.
Contributions may be made to
American Heart Association.
